entry.title: Numpy í¸ì˜ê¸°ëŠ¥ ë° ê¸°ë³¸ì¡°ì‘ 1 ~ 3
entry.content:
Numpy í¸ì˜ê¸°ëŠ¥ ë° ê¸°ë³¸ì¡°ì‘

np.eye(row, {col}, {band_id}, {dtype}) : bandì— 1 ì±„ì›Œë„£ê¸°

  • 0,0 ì„ ê¸°ì¤€ìœ¼ë¡œ ëŒ€ê°ì„  í•­ -> band

np.identity(num, {dtype}) : identity matrix

  • Same as np.eye(3) : 3x3 ë§¤íŠ¸ë¦­ìŠ¤

np.tri(row, {col}, {k=band_id}, {dtype}) : lower triangular matrix

  • nonzero entry = 1

  • a = np.eye(row, {col},{band_id}, {dtype})

  • K <= band id ì˜ ëª¨ë“  ë°´ë“œì— 1ì„ ì±„ì›Œë„£ê³  ë‚˜ë¨¸ì§€ëŠ” 0 ì„ ì±„ì›€

np.tril(a, {k=band_id}) : band_idë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•œ lower ë¶€ë¶„ì„ copy

np.triu(a, {k=band_id}) : band_idë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•œ upper ë¶€ë¶„ì„ copy

np.full((row, col), value) : ì§€ì •ëœ ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ ì±„ìš°ê¸°

np.randomn.rand(row, col)

  • ë°ì´í„°íƒ€ì… ì§€ì • ë¶ˆê°€ -> np.float64 ê³ ì •
  • 0ê³¼ 1 ì‚¬ì´ ë¬´ì‘ìœ„ ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ ì±„ì›Œì§

np.copy(a) : ì„œë¡œ ê°™ì€ ë©”ëª¨ë¦¬ë¥¼ ì°¸ì¡° : í•˜ë‚˜ê°€ ë³€í•˜ë©´ ë‹¤ë¥¸ í•˜ë‚˜ë„ ë³€í•¨

np.reshape(a, vector or shape)

  • np.reshape(a, 6) : 1D array
  • np.reshape(a, (3, 2)) : 2D array

np.diag(a, k=band_id) : band ì¶”ì¶œ í›„ 1D arrayë¡œ ë§Œë“¦

  • b is READ ONLY
  • ë™ì¼ ë©”ëª¨ë¦¬ ê³µê°„ ì°¸ì¡°
  • ì…ë ¥ì´ 1D array (ë²¡í„°)ì´ë©´ square í–‰ë ¬ ìƒì„±

np.diagflat(M, k=band_id) : Më¥¼ 1Dí™” í•œë’¤ì— square matrix ìƒì„±

np.trace(a, offset=band_id)

  • diagonal entry ( band entry )ë¥¼ ë”í•œ ê°’
  • \(\left[\begin{matrix}\\1 & 2 & 3 \\1 & 2 & 3 \\1 & 2 & 3 \\ \end{matrix}\right]\) â†’ np.trace(a) returns 15, np.trace(a, offset=-1) returns 12

np.hstack((tuple)) : ìˆ˜í‰ìœ¼ë¡œ ìŒ“ì•„ê° - tuple ìˆœì„œëŒ€ë¡œ í–‰(row, shape[0]) ê°œìˆ˜ê°€ ë§ì•„ì•¼ í•¨

np.vstack((tuple)) : ìˆ˜ì§ìœ¼ë¡œ ìŒ“ì•„ê° - tuple ìˆœì„œëŒ€ë¡œ í–‰(col, shape[0]) ê°œìˆ˜ê°€ ë§ì•„ì•¼ í•¨

Methods

transpose() method

  • ë‹¨, 1d arrëŠ” ë¬´ë³€

flatten method

  • í–‰ë ¬ aë¥¼ 1d array ë¡œ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ copy

  • Same as np.ravel(a)

Properties

real : ì‹¤ìˆ˜ ë¶€ë¶„

imag : í—ˆìˆ˜ ë¶€ë¶„

conjegate: copy

Matrix Multiplication

M1 @ M2 or np.matmul(M1, M2)

*** or / is not multiplication !! **

Matrix-Vector Product

M @ arr or np.matmul(M, arr)

Inner Product

np.dot() is â€¦

  • Real vector same as vdot()
  • complex vector : conjugateê°€ ë¹ ì§„ ì±„ë¡œ ê³„ì‚°

entry.title: í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ - ê¸°ëŠ¥ê°œë°œ
entry.content:
ì˜¤ëŠ˜ì˜ ë¬¸ì œ

í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ ê¸°ëŠ¥ê°œë°œ

ë™ì¼í•œ í¬ê¸°ì˜ ë‘ ê°œì˜ ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ë¥¼ ê³„ì‚°í•œë‹¤. ì•ë³´ë‹¤ ë’¤ ê°’ì´ ì‘ìœ¼ë©´ ì¹´ìš´íŠ¸ í•´ì¤€ë‹¤.

í’€ì´ ë°©ë²•

progresses = [93, 30, 55]
speeds = [1, 30, 5]
# return [2, 1]

temp_result = [math.ceil((100 - prog) / sp) for prog, sp in zip(progresses, speeds)]
# return [7, 3, 9]

0ë²ˆì§¸ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ 93í¼ì„¼íŠ¸ ì§„í–‰ë¥ ì˜ í•˜ë£¨ 1í¼ì„¼íŠ¸ì˜ ì†ë„ë¥¼ ë³´ì¸ë‹¤. 7ì¼ í›„ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì™„ë£Œëœë‹¤.

ì´ëŸ° ì‹ì´ë‹¤. ì™„ë£Œì‹œì (100í¼ì„¼íŠ¸)ê¹Œì§€ ê³„ì‚°ì€ ì‰½ë‹¤. ë‚¨ì€ ì§„ì²™ë„ë¥¼ êµ¬í•˜ê³  ìŠ¤í”¼ë“œë¥¼ ë‚˜ëˆ ì¤€ í›„ , ì†Œìˆ«ì ì€ ë¬´ì¡°ê±´ ì˜¬ë ¤ì£¼ë©´ ëœë‹¤.

ì—¬ê¸°ê¹Œì§„ ì˜ì´ì§€~

answer = 1
retval = list()

for idx in range(1, len(temp_result)):
    if temp_result[idx-1] < temp_result[idx]:
        retval.append(answer)
        answer = 1
    else:
        temp_result[idx] = temp_result[idx-1]
        answer += 1
        
retval.append(answer)

i-1 ë²ˆì§¸ê°€ ië²ˆì§¸ë³´ë‹¤ í¬ë©´ ê²°ê³¼ ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì— ì‚½ì…í•˜ê³  1ë¡œ ì´ˆê¸°í™” í•´ì¤€ë‹¤.

i-1 ë²ˆì§¸ê°€ ië²ˆì§¸ë³´ë‹¤ ì‘ìœ¼ë©´, i-1ë²ˆì§¸ëŠ” ê·¸ ë„˜ì–´ì˜ ìˆ«ìì™€ ë¹„êµë˜ì–´ì•¼í•˜ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, i ë²ˆì§¸ì— ë„£ì–´ì£¼ê³  answer( count )ë¥¼ í•˜ë‚˜ ì˜¬ë ¤ì£¼ê³  forë¬¸ì„ ì§€ì†í•œë‹¤.

ì‚¬ë‹´

ì§„ì§œ ì•„ì‰¬ì› ë‹¤â€¦ ë‹¤ í’€ì—ˆëŠ”ë°â€¦ ë‚´ê°€ 24ì‹œê°„ì„ ê¼¬ë°• ìƒœê³ â€¦ ë‘í†µì´ ì—„ì²­ ì™€ì„œ ëª» í‘¼ ê±°ë‹¤â€¦ ê·¸ëŸ°ê±°ë‹¤ ^^

entry.title: í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ - ë©€ì©¡í•œ ì‚¬ê°í˜•
entry.content:
ì˜¤ëŠ˜ì˜ ë¬¸ì œ

í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ ë©€ì©¡í•œ ì‚¬ê°í˜•

ë¬¸ì œ ê°„ëµ ì„¤ëª… : 12 by 8 ë°°ì—´ì˜ ì‚¬ê°í˜•ì—ì„œ ëŒ€ê°ì„ ì˜ ë¶ˆëŠ¥ì„ ì œì™¸ í›„ ê°œìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì„¸ì–´ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ë¬¸ì œ

í’€ì´ ë°©ë²•

ë¬¸ì œì˜ ë‹µì„ ì§ê´€ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì•Œ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤. ê°€ë¡œ 2ì”© ì„¸ë¡œ 3ì”© ì¦ê°€í•˜ê³ , 3 by 2ì˜ ë„í˜• ì•ˆì—ì„œ ë¶ˆëŠ¥ ë„í˜•ì˜ ê°œìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì°¾ê³ , ì´ íŒ¨í„´ì´ ëª‡ ë²ˆ ë°˜ë³µë˜ëŠ”ì§€ ì•Œì•„ë‚´ë©´ ëœë‹¤ !

8 â†’ 2, 12 â†’ 3 ë‹ˆê¹Œ 4 ! â†’ 4ë²ˆ íŒ¨í„´ì´ ë°˜ë³µë˜ëŠ” ê±´ ë‘ ìˆ˜ ì‚¬ì´ì˜ ìµœëŒ€ê³µì•½ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì°¾ì•„ì£¼ë©´ ëœë‹¤.

3 by 2 ì€ 6ê°œ ì¤‘ 4ê°œê°€ ë¶ˆëŠ¥, 12 by 8 ì€ 96ê°œ ì¤‘ 16ê°œê°€ ë¶ˆëŠ¥ì´ë‹¤.

ì£¼ì–´ì§„ ê°€ë¡œì™€ ì„¸ë¡œì— ìµœëŒ€ê³µì•½ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë‚˜ëˆ„ì–´ì£¼ê³  -1ì„ í•œë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ¬ê³  ë°˜ë³µë˜ëŠ” íŒ¨í„´ì´ 4ë²ˆ (12ì™€ 8ì˜ ìµœëŒ€ê³µì•½ìˆ˜)ì´ë‹ˆ ì´ë§Œí¼ ê³±í•´ì¤€ë‹¤! â€¦ìµœëŒ€ê³µì•½ìˆ˜ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” êµ¬ê¸€ë§í•´ì„œ ì£¼ì› ë‹¤. ã…ã… ê·¼ë° math ëª¨ë“ˆì— ìˆë”ë¼ê³ ? ì•”íŠ¼

((w / gcd(w, h) + h / gcd(w, h)) - 1 ) * gcd(w, h)

ê·¸ëŸ¬ê³  ì „ì²´ ë„í˜•ì—ì„œ ë¶ˆëŠ¥ ë„í˜•ì˜ ê°œìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë¹¼ì£¼ë©´ ë~

ì‚¬ë‹´

ê°œì¸ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì§ê´€ì ì¸ ë¬¸ì œëŠ” ë¬´ì‹í•˜ê²Œ í’€ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤ê³  ìƒê°í•˜ê¸°ì—â€¦ ë¹ˆ ì¢…ì´ì— ì†ìœ¼ë¡œ ì“°ë©´ì„œ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ í’€ì—ˆë‹¤.

ëŒ€ê°ì„ ì´ ì§€ë‚˜ê°ˆ ë•Œì˜ ë¶ˆëŠ¥ ë„í˜•ì˜ ê°œìˆ˜ê°€ ì œì¼ ë¨¸ë¦¬ ì•„íŒ ë‹¤â€¦ ë­ë„ê¹Œ ì• ê¸° ë•Œ ìˆ˜í•™ ê³µë¶€ë¥¼ ì˜í–ˆìœ¼ë©´ ê¸ˆë°© í’€ì—ˆì„í…ë° í•˜ëŠ” ìƒê°ì´ ë“¤ ì •ë„ë¡œ ê°„ë‹¨í•´ë³´ì´ëŠ”ë° ì˜ ëª¨ë¥´ê² ê³ â€¦ ì´ê²Œ ë§ëŠ”ë° ì™œ ê·¸ëŸ°ì§€ëŠ” ëª¨ë¥´ê² ëŠ” ê·¸ëŸ° ë„ˆë‚Œ

ì§ê´€ì ì¸ ë¬¸ì œ â†’ ë¬´ì‹í•˜ê²Œ í’€ê¸° ê°€ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ê·¸ëƒ¥ ë¬´ì‹í•œ ë‚˜ë„ í’€ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤ëŠ” ê±¸ ì•Œê²Œëë‹¤â€¦ğŸ¥²

entry.title: Ch14. The Matrix Equation Ax=b
entry.content:
\(A\mathbf{x}\) : Product of A and x

The linear combination of the columns of \(A\) using the corresponding entries in \(\mathbf{X} \mbox{ as weights}\) â†’ x ë²¡í„° ì—”íŠ¸ë¦¬ê°€ ê°€ì¤‘ì¹˜

ğŸ“– Theorem 3.

\(A\) is \(m \times n\) matrix, with columns \(a_1, \cdots, a_n \mathbf{b} \mbox{ is in }\mathbb{R}^m\)

  1. Matrix Equation : \(A\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}\)
  2. Vector Equation : \(x_1\mathbf{a_1} + x_2\mathbf{a_2} + \cdots + x_p\mathbf{a_p} = \mathbb{b}\)
  3. Augmented Matrix : \(\left[ \mathbf{a_1}, \mathbf{a_2}, \cdots, \mathbf{a_n} \mathbf{b}\right]\)

Have the same solution set!

ğŸ“– Theorem 4.

The followings are all true of all false:

  1. For each b in R^m, Ax = b has a solution
  2. Each b in R^m is a linear combination of the columns of A
  3. The columns of A spanR^m
  4. A has a pivot position in every row

ğŸ“– Theorem 5.

If A is an m x n matrix, u and v are vectors in R^m, And c is a scalar, then;
A(u + v) = Au + Av;
A(cu) = c(Au)
entry.summary: \(A\mathbf{x}\) : Product of A and x The linear combination of the columns of \(A\) using the corresponding entries in \(\mathbf{X} \mbox{ as weights}\) â†’ x ë²¡í„° ì—”íŠ¸ë¦¬ê°€ ê°€ì¤‘ì¹˜

entry.title: Ch13. Vector Equations
entry.content:
Vectors in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) â†’ ì‹¤ìˆ˜ 2ì°¨ì› ê³µê°„
\(\mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ -1 \\\end{matrix}\right], \mathbf{v} = \left[\begin{matrix}0.2 \\ 0.3 \\\end{matrix}\right], \mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}w_1 \\ w_2 \\\end{matrix}\right]\)
\(\vec{u} = (3, -1), \vec{v} = (0.2, 0.3), \vec{w} = (w_1, w_2)\)

\[(w_1, w_2) \ne \left[ w_1, w_2\right]\]

Scalar Multiplication

ë°±í„° ë„¤ ëª¨ë“  ê°’ì— ìŠ¤ì¹¼ë¼ ê°’ì„ ê³±í•´ì¤€ë‹¤
\(c = 5, \mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ -1 \\\end{matrix}\right]\) ì¼ ë•Œ,
\(c\mathbf{u} = 5 \left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ -1 \\\end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix}5\cdot3 \\ 5\cdot(-1) \\\end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix}15 \\ -5 \\\end{matrix}\right]\)

Vectors in \(\mathbb{R}^n\)

\(c\mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}u_1 \\ u_2 \\ \cdots \\ u_n\end{matrix}\right] \\ \mathbf{u} = (u_1, u_2, \cdots, u_n)\)

Algebraic Properties of \(\mathbb{R}^n\)

\(\mathbf{u, v, w} \mbox{ are } \mathbb{R}^n \mbox{ and } c d \mbox{ are scalar}\)

  1. u + v = v + u
  2. (u + v) + w = u + (v + w)
  3. u + 0 = 0 + u = u
  4. u + (-u) = -u + u = 0
  5. c(u + v) = cu + cv
  6. (c + d)u = cu + du
  7. c(du) = (cd)u
  8. 1u = u

Linear Combinations

Linear combination of \(\mathbf{v_1, v_2, \cdots, v_p} \mbox{ is } \mathbb{R}^n \mbox{with weights } c_1, c_2, \cdots, c_p \mbox{ is scalar}\)

y = \(c_1\mathbf{v_1} + c_2\mathbf{v_2} + \cdots + c_p\mathbf{v_p}\)

A vector equation
\(x_1\mathbf{a_1}+x_2\mathbf{a_2}+\cdots+x_n\mathbf{a_n} = \mathbf{b}\)
has the same solution set as the linear system whose augmented matrix is
\(\left[\mathbf{a_1} \mathbf{a_2} \cdots \mathbf{a_n} \mathbf{b}\right]\)

â†’ ê° ë²¡í„°ë¥¼ ì§‘ì–´ë„£ì€ Augmented Matrix ì™€ ë™ì¼í•œ í•´ë¥¼ ì§€ë‹Œë‹¤.

Span{\(\mathbf{v}\)}

is the collection of all vectors that can be written in the form
\(c_1\mathbf{v_1} + c_2\mathbf{v_2} + \cdots + c_p\mathbf{v_p}\)
entry.summary: Vectors in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) â†’ ì‹¤ìˆ˜ 2ì°¨ì› ê³µê°„ \(\mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ -1 \\\end{matrix}\right], \mathbf{v} = \left[\begin{matrix}0.2 \\ 0.3 \\\end{matrix}\right], \mathbf{u} = \left[\begin{matrix}w_1 \\ w_2 \\\end{matrix}\right]\) \(\vec{u} = (3, -1), \vec{v} = (0.2, 0.3), \vec{w} = (w_1, w_2)\)

entry.title: Ch12. Row Reduction and Echelon Forms

link.title: Ch12. Row Reduction and Echelon Forms

entry.content:
A leading Entry of row : the LEFTMOST nonzero entry.

Echelon Form

  1. All nonzero rows are above any rows of all zeros
  2. Each leading entry of a row is in column to the right of the leading entry of the row above it
  3. The leading entry in each nonzero row is 1
  4. Each leading 1 is the only nonzero entry in its column
\[1 â†’ \left[ \begin{matrix} \bullet & * & * & * \\ 0 & \bullet & * & * \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \end{matrix} \right] 2 â†’ \left[ \begin{matrix} \bullet & * & * & * \\ 0 & \bullet & * & * \\ 0 & 0 & \bullet & * \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & \bullet \\ \end{matrix} \right]\]

ğŸ“– Theorem 1. Uniqueness of the Reduced Echelon Form

Each matrix is row equivalent to one and only one reduced echelon matrix

Row Reduction Algorithm

  1. Begin with the leftmost nonzero column
  2. Select a nonzero entry in the pivot column as a pivot. If necessary, Interchange rows to move this entry into the pivot position.
  3. Row replacement to create zeros in all positions below the pivot.
  4. Apply steps 1-3 to the sub matrix that remain. The combination of steps 1-4 is called forward phase echelon form
  5. Beginning with the rightmost polio and working upward and to the left, created zeros above each pivot. If a pivot is not 1, make it 1 by a scaling operation.
    • Called backward phase reduced echelon form

Solution of linear systems

\(\left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 0 & -5 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \end{matrix} \right]\)
ì¼ ë•Œ,
\(x_1 - 5x_3 = 1 \\ x_2 + x_3 = 4 \\ 0 = 0 \\ \left[ \begin{matrix} 6 \\3 \\1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} -9 \\ 6 \\ -2 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \cdots\)
í•´ê°€ ë¬´í•œëŒ€ê°€ ë˜ë©°, General Solution ì€ ì•„ë˜ì™€ ê°™ë‹¤.
\(\begin{cases} x_1 = 1 + 5x_3 & \mbox{basic / leading variables} \\ x_2 = 4 - x_3 & \mbox{basic / leading variables} \\ x_3 \mbox{ is free} & \mbox{free variable} \end{cases}\)

ğŸ“– Theorem 2. Existence and Uniqueness Theorem

A linear system is consistent if and only if the rightmost column of the augmented matrix is not a pivot column - that is, if and only if and echelon form of the augmented matrix has no row of the forms.
\(\left[ \begin{matrix} 0 & \cdots & 0 & b \end{matrix} \right]\) with \(b\) is nonzero.
If a linear system is consistent, then the solution set contains either (i) a unique solution, when there are no free variables, or (ii) infinitely many solutions, when there is at least one free variables.
entry.summary: A leading Entry of row : the LEFTMOST nonzero entry. Echelon Form All nonzero rows are above any rows of all zeros Each leading entry of a row is in column to the right of the leading entry of the row above it The leading entry in each nonzero row is 1 Each leading 1 is the only nonzero entry in its column

entry.title: Ch11. Linear Equations in Linear Algebra

link.title: Ch11. Linear Equations in Linear Algebra

entry.content:
A system of linear equations : A collection of one or more linear equations
Solution Set : The Set of all possible solutions of the linear system
â†’ Two linear systems are called equivalent if they have the same solution set.

A system of linear equations has either

  1. No Solution ( INCONSISTENT )
  2. Exactly one Solution ( CONSISTENT )
  3. Infinitely Many Solutions ( CONSISTENT )

Matrix Notation

  • 3 rows x 3 columns => Coefficient Matrix ( 3 \(\times\) 3 ) : ê³„ìˆ˜ í–‰ë ¬
  • 3 rows x 4 columns => Augmented Matrix ( 3 \(\times\) 4 ) : í™•ëŒ€ í–‰ë ¬
    • ì²¨ê°€ í–‰ë ¬ì€ ê³„ìˆ˜ í–‰ë ¬ê³¼ ìƒìˆ˜í•­ë“¤ì˜ í–‰ë ¬ì„ ë§ë¶™ì—¬ ì–»ëŠ” í–‰ë ¬

Augmented Matrix

\(A = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 7 & 4 \\ 1 & 6 & 8 \\ \end{matrix} \right] , B = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 \\ 4 \\ 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right]\) ê°€ ìˆì„ ë•Œ, Augmented Matrix ëŠ” \(\left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1\\ 4 & 7 & 4 & 4 \\ 1 & 6 & 8 & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right]\) ì´ë‹¤.

Elementary row operations

  1. Replacement
  2. Interchange
  3. Scaling

Two matrices are Row Equivalent If there is a sequence of elementary row operations that transforms one matrix into the other.
If the augmented matrices of the linear systems are row equivalent, then the two systems have the same solution set.
entry.summary: A system of linear equations : A collection of one or more linear equations Solution Set : The Set of all possible solutions of the linear system â†’ Two linear systems are called equivalent if they have the same solution set.

entry.title: í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ í¬ë¡¤ë§
entry.content:
21ë…„ 1ì›”ë¶€í„° ì—°êµ¬ì‹¤ì—ì„  ë§¤ì¼ ì˜¤ì „ 9ì‹œ 30ë¶„ë¶€í„° í•œ ì‹œê°„ë™ì•ˆ íŒŒì´ì¬ ì•Œê³ ë¦¬ì¦˜ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ í‘¼ë‹¤.

êµìˆ˜ë‹˜ê»˜ì„œ í•œ ì‚¬ëŒì”© ëŒì•„ê°€ë©´ì„œ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ ê°€ì ¸ì˜¤ë¼ê³  ì§€ì •í•˜ì…¨ê³ , í•œ ì‚¬ì´í´ì´ ì§€ë‚˜ê³ ë¶€í„°ëŠ” ì˜¤ëŠ˜ì€ ëˆ„êµ°ì§€ ê²ë‚˜ê²Œ~ í—·ê°ˆë¦¬ê¸° ì‹œì‘í–ˆê³ , ëˆ„ê°€ ìŠ¤í”„ë¦°íŠ¸ë¥¼ ë¹ ì§„ë‹¤ê³  í•˜ë©´ ê·¸ë•Œë¶€í„° ë¶ˆì•ˆí–ˆë‹¤. ë‚˜ë§Œ ê¸°ì–µ ëª»í•˜ë‚˜ ì‹¶ì„ ì •ë„ë¡œ ë¬´ë¤ë¤í•œ ì‚¬ëŒë“¤ â€¦ ã… ì–´ë–¤ ë‚ ì€ ì„œë¡œ ìê¸°ì¸ ì¤„ ì•Œì•˜ë‹¤ë©° ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ ë‘ ëª…ì´ ë“¤ê³ ì˜¨ ì ë„ ìˆì—ˆëŠ”ë°. ì´ê²Œ ë‚´ ì„±ê²©ì´ê¸´ í•œë°â€¦ ì •ë¦¬ë˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ ìƒíƒœâ€¦ ë‚˜ì˜ê²Œ ë§í•˜ë©´ ì•„ë…¸ë¯¸ ìƒíƒœã…‹ã…‹ã…‹ã…‹ê°€ ì‹«ë‹¤. ì‹œê°„ì„ ì¡°ê¸ˆë§Œ íˆ¬ìí•˜ë©´ ì˜ ì •ëˆëœ ìƒíƒœë¥¼ ë§Œë“¤ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ”ë°â€¦ ê·¸ ìƒí™©ì— ë‚´ê°€ í¬í•¨ë˜ì–´ ìˆë‹¤ë©´ ë°œë²—ê³  ë‚˜ì„œì•¼ì§€ ë­â€¦ ëª©ë§ˆë¥¸ ì‚¬ëŒì´ ìš°ë¬¼ íŒŒë‹ˆê¹Œ

ê·¸ëƒ¥ í¬ë¡¤ë§ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì§°ë‹¤. í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë¨¸ìŠ¤ ì‚¬ì´íŠ¸ê°€ SPA ì¸ì§€ ë­”ì§€ ì•„ë¬´íŠ¼ urlë¡œ ë°˜ì‘í•˜ëŠ”ê²Œ ì•„ë‹ˆì—ˆê³ , ëª¨ë“  ë¬¸ì œê°€ ëª¨ë“  ì–¸ì–´ë¡œ í’€ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ê±´ ì•„ë‹ˆì—ˆë‹¤. íŠ¹ì • ë ˆë²¨ì˜ íŠ¹ì • ì–¸ì–´ë¥¼ ê°€ì ¸ì™€ì•¼ í–ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ë”ëŸ½ê²Œ ê·€ì°®ì•„ë³´ì˜€ì§€ë§Œâ€¦ ê·¸ë˜ë„ ì†ê°€ë½ì„ ë½‘ì•˜ìœ¼ë©´ ì½”ë“œ í•œ ì¤„ì´ë¼ë„ ì°ì–´ì•¼ ëŒ€ì¥ë¶€ë‹ˆê¹Œ ^^

entry.title: THEOREMs
entry.content:
ğŸ“– Theorem 1.

Uniqueness of the Reduced Echelon Form Each matrix is row equivalent to one and only one reduced echelon matrix

ğŸ“– Theorem 2.

ğŸ“– Theorem 3.

\(A\) is \(m \times n\) matrix, with columns \(a_1, \cdots, a_n \mathbf{b} \mbox{ is in }\mathbb{R}^m\)

  1. Matrix Equation : \(A\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}\)
  2. Vector Equation : \(x_1\mathbf{a_1} + x_2\mathbf{a_2} + \cdots + x_p\mathbf{a_p} = \mathbb{b}\)
  3. Augmented Matrix : \(\left[ \mathbf{a_1}, \mathbf{a_2}, \cdots, \mathbf{a_n} \mathbf{b}\right]\)

Have the same solution set!

ğŸ“– Theorem 4.

The followings are all true of all false:

  1. For each b in R^m, Ax = b has a solution
  2. Each b in R^m is a linear combination of the columns of A
  3. The columns of A spanR^m
  4. A has a pivot position in every row

ğŸ“– Theorem 5.

If A is an m x n matrix, u and v are vectors in R^m, And c is a scalar, then;
A(u + v) = Au + Av;
A(cu) = c(Au)
entry.summary: ğŸ“– Theorem 1. Uniqueness of the Reduced Echelon Form Each matrix is row equivalent to one and only one reduced echelon matrix

entry.title: Ch18. The Matrix of a Linear Transformation

link.title: Ch18. The Matrix of a Linear Transformation

entry.content:
ğŸ“– Theorem 10.

Let \(T : \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) be a linear transformation. Then there exists a unique matrix A such that
\(T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x} \mbox{ for all }\mathbf{x} \mbox{ in }\mathbb{R^n}\)
In fact, \(A\) is the \(m \times n\) matrix whose j-th column is the vector \(T(e_j)\), where \(e_j\) is the j-th column of the identity matrix in \(\mathbb{R^n}\):
\(A = \left[ T(e_1) \cdots T(e_n) \right]\)
Standard matrix for the linear transformation T

Onto

A mapping \(T: \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) is said to be onto \(\mathbb{R^m}\) if each \(\mathbf{b}\) in \(\mathbb{R^m}\) is the image of at least one \(\mathbf{x}\) in \(\mathbb{R^n}\)

One-to-one

A mapping \(T: \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) is said to be one-to-one if each \(\mathbf{b}\) in \(\mathbb{R^m}\) is the image of at most one \(\mathbf{x}\) in \(\mathbb{R^n}\)

  • ì—¬ëŸ¬ ê°œì˜ ë²¡í„°ì—ì„œ ê°™ì€ ì´ë¯¸ì§€ë¡œ ë„ë‹¬í•  ë•Œ : one-to-oneì´ ì•„ë‹˜
  • 1ëŒ€1 ëŒ€ì‘ : one-to-one

ğŸ“– Theorem 11.

Let \(T: \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) be a linear transformation.
Then \(T\) is one-to-one if and only if the equation \(T(\mathbf{x}) = 0\) has only trivial solution.
\(T(0) = T(0\mathbf{0}) = 0T(\mathbf{0})\\ T(\mathbf{u} = \mathbf{b} T(\mathbf{v} = b)\\ T(\mathbf{u} - \mathbf{v}) = T(\mathbf{u}) - T(\mathbf{v}) = 0\\ \mathbf{u} - \mathbf{v} \ne 0\)
\(T(\mathbf{x}) = 0\) has more than one solution

ğŸ“– Theorem 12.

Let \(T: \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) be a linear transformation and let \(A\) be the standard matrix for \(T\).
Then \(T\) maps \(\mathbb{R^n} \mbox{onto} \mathbb{R^m}\) if and only if the columns of \(A\) span \(\mathbb{R^m}\)
\(T\) is one-to-one if and only if the columns of \(A\) are linearly independent.
one-to-one â†’ only trivial â†’ independent
entry.summary: ğŸ“– Theorem 10. Let \(T : \mathbb{R^n} \to \mathbb{R^m}\) be a linear transformation. Then there exists a unique matrix A such that \(T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x} \mbox{ for all }\mathbf{x} \mbox{ in }\mathbb{R^n}\) In fact, \(A\) is the \(m \times n\) matrix whose j-th column is the vector \(T(e_j)\), where \(e_j\) is the j-th column of the identity matrix in \(\mathbb{R^n}\): \(A = \left[ T(e_1) \cdots T(e_n) \right]\) Standard matrix for the linear transformation T
